values:
Well its been an age since I posted anything, mainly as its been so long since I have written anything.  However, the below was written in response to a challange elsewhere called 'The Stranger'.  Thought I may as well post it.  Its an Alexander/Hephaistion story and is a sort of prequal/sequal to another story called 'The Boy in the Courtyard' which I posted a long time ago.


 

I started to fall in love with Alexander the first time that I saw him.  He didn’t know who I was then, but I knew he soon would with a certainty that I had never felt before or since.  I knew because it had been foretold me. 

I spent my formative years in Athens.  I was born in Pella but my father’s father was Athenian and when I was but a year old we moved back to Athens.  I never knew why my father uprooted us or how he came to be in Macedonia in the first place.  What I did know was that I never felt that I belonged there.  As I grew and began to understand the world around me my Macedonian birthplace called to me.  That was where the future was and I desperately wanted to be a part of it.

I pleaded with my Father to go back to Macedonia but he refused until I was in my thirteenth year when he finally declared that the time had come to return.  Again, what prompted this move was never made clear and I was too happy to question it.

The day before we were due to leave, I left the house early in the morning to have a last look around.  I knew not if I would ever see Athens again and wanted to take one final look.  I was not allowed to walk around unattended but knew by slipping out just after dawn no-one would notice that I had gone.

It was when I reached the Agora that I saw her.  She was old and unkempt.  No-one knew who she was or where she came from and she would disappear sometimes for months before suddenly reappearing again.  To tell the truth she had always unsettled me.  I could not help but feel that she was watching me and it made me uneasy.  On seeing her therefore, I turned about to head in a different direction when I heard her call my name. 

I stopped at first thinking that I must have imagined it but then I heard her again.  I turned slowly and as I did so, saw her beckoning me over.  My first instinct was to run, but then I looked into her eyes and suddenly felt compelled to go to her.  I was nervous as I drew near but she smiled and suddenly she did not appear to be so frightening.  She spoke again and told me not to be fearful but she had things to tell me as I was the ‘Special One’.  I knew if my friends could hear her now they would say that she was crazy and me stupid for taking notice of her, but I couldn’t help it.  I felt that I had to know what she was going to say.

I asked her how she knew my name and she told me she had always known it.  She had been waiting for the right time to talk to me and that time was now.   I sat before her and she placed her hand on my shoulder and began to talk. 

She told me that I was going to meet my destiny.  That I was to be given a great responsibility but that I would learn to cope with this, as the Gods never give us more than we can bear.  I didn’t understand and asked what this destiny was.  She smiled again.  My destiny she said, would find me.  It would be a bright shining thing full of light and life.  I asked her how I would recognise it and she smiled again. I would know him when I saw him.  Him I asked?  She shook her head.  She could tell me no more other than my life would be difficult sometimes, however I would know great love which would see me through.  And that was it.  She smiled for the last time and said that it was time I went.  I did not want to leave as I had so many questions but she said that I must learn the rest for myself and she would speak no more to me.  I asked her numerous questions but she shut her eyes and was silent. 

It was now starting to get busy and suddenly I felt self conscious and concerned about being seen with the old woman as only a young boy can be, so I turned and walked away.  As I did so I heard her sigh and say ‘The Gods have chosen well both here and in Pella’.  I turned back but she had gone.  I looked all around but could not see her.  There was nothing more that I could do, so I made my way home and as I had thought managed to get back before anyone noticed that I had gone.

I thought on the old woman’s words for the rest of the day and all that night too excited by the thought of the upcoming departure to sleep anyway but they made no sense to me and by the time that we had reached Pella I gave them no thought at all, pushed aside by the experiences of the journey.

On our arrival my Father arranged for me to attend the Court for Page training.  It was all I wanted.  Finally I would be at the centre of things and my life could begin.

Thus it was that I found myself in one of the Palace courtyards talking to Ptolemy who had taken me under his wing and was trying his best to make me at ease in my new life.  It was then that I first saw Alexander.  He was standing on a balcony overlooking the courtyard arguing with an older man who I later discovered was Leonidas.  The sun was shining on him and for a moment I was transfixed. 

Ptolemy, who realised that I was not paying attention to him, told me that the boy was Alexander who I would no doubt meet at some point.  He then made some joke which I cannot now recall but which made me laugh at the time.  In fact I can recall nothing more of what he said.

My mind was reeling.  Although I had not spoken to Alexander I had felt an immediate connection with him.  I knew without looking that he was watching me.  All of a sudden, I recalled the words of the old woman and knew with a certainty that my bright shining destiny was before me.  It was Alexander.

I wanted to go and find him there and then but knew that I had to wait, that he had to come to me.  It was ordained that way and sure enough the next night it happened.

He crept into the boy’s dormitory.  I was not asleep and so heard him approach.  He crouched by my bed and spoke to me for the first time.

“My name is Alexander”.

“I know who you are Alexander” I replied “I’ve been waiting for you” and so it began.

The old woman was right.  My life is difficult sometimes (and so it has to be said is Alexander).  But the love that we share makes up for any difficulties or hardships.  I told Alexander once what I had been told and he told me that he too would call me the ‘Special One’.  I told him that if he did he would never share my bed again and so far he has refrained.  We did not talk of it again.

I have not seen the old woman since and think that maybe I never will.  I did return to Athens once, after the battle of Charonea and whilst I was there I went looking for her but to no avail.  I believe therefore that she will remain forever a stranger, but when I look at Alexander maybe that does not matter.   She prepared me for what was to come and for that I will always be grateful.

Having posted this elsewhere I figured I might as well put it here as well.  It is not a subject that I would have written about, but was inspired by a fic challenge elsewhere.

Title: A Living Death
Pairing: ALexander/Hephaistion
Spoilers/Warnings: Death Fic.  Alexanders thoughts on Hephaistions death.


<lj-cut>

Fools.  They think that I am over him.  Its been five months.  Five months and they think that everything is back to normal.  They never understood what is was like.  The irresistible force which drove us together and kept us there.  Together for twenty years and they think that a few months can heal a heart torn asunder, a soul crying out in despair.

Do they not understand what it is like to dream night after night that he is still with me, laughing with me, admonishing me, loving me, only to wake and find myself alone once again.   

To look for him in every room you enter and pray that this once he will be there, standing in the corner  quietly watching as was his wont.

To relive that terrible day over and over and to wish with everything possible that this time you will reach him before it is too late.   To remember that dreadful moment when the door opened and you saw him lying unmoving on the bed, eyes sightless but still so very beautiful.  

To live with the guilt that the one time he needed you most you were not there for him, when he had spent his whole life being there for you.

To scream at the Gods at the injustice of taking this man from you when you still needed him so.

To remember the good times that we had and the bad and to know that no one now shares these memories, they are yours alone.  

No, they do not understand.  How could they?  The irony is that he is the only one that would.  He always understood.  Right from the beginning.  

We were 12 when we first met.  A day like any other.  There were no portents of what was to come.  The Gods were quiet that day, the day that would change my life forever.

At 15 we exchanged our first kiss.  Most people thought we had done so long before.  But they knew nothing of us.  They thought it was a boys infatuation.  We knew differently.  It was love, from the beginning and for ever after.  We knew there was no need to rush.  After all we thought we had forever.

We became intimate at 16.  Our souls had long been united, but now it was time to unite our bodies as well.  We were young and inexperienced but it was no less perfect for that.

At 20 everything changed.  We were men with roles, responsibilities and power.  It was exciting and frightening at the same time.  But as long as we were together, nothing was too difficult or daunting.  

We became warriors.  We fought together, killed too many men to count and  were wounded in return.  We besieged Tyre.  He said I was being pig headed and maybe he was right.  I told him it was about honour and principle and maybe I was right too.  He liked to build bridges.  I teased him about that.  He laughed and said that construction was better than destruction and maybe I could learn a thing or too about that.  We entered Babylon, him at my side.  Such a glorious day.  I killed Cleitus, the worst day of my life I thought.  Little did I know then. 

So many memories.

We died at 32.  Him physically and myself in every way it is possible to die whilst still breathing. You must be dead  when the world is no longer a place you want to inhabit and when everything that made life bearable is gone.

Is it too late to tell him all the things that I should have said?  Will he still hear me?  I have to believe that we will meet again, should I wait until then?  But how long will that be?  It would be easy to succumb and join him now.  So much harder to carry on, for this is what I must do.  It is the last thing that he would expect of me.  But I have but one aim left in this life and that is to join him.  I pray that the time will not be long.  

</lj-cut>

I seem to spend so much time reading everyones LJ that I have no time to udate my own.  Have therefore decided that I will update on an occasional basis as and when I have anything of interest or when I write any fiction rather than every day. I admire people who do make the time and effort to do this however they are obviously more disciplined and manage their time better than I do.

O.K, I think I am starting to get the hang of this now, and feel very pleased with myself that I can post two fics (though this has required a little help, it has to be said).  They are both about Horatio/Archie and can be found

here

<lj-cut>

After Muzillac

We had just come down from the mast which Archie had insisted we climb and I was lying in his arms in our cabin where I belong.  I knew the question that he wanted to ask, had been asking myself the same thing and I knew that it would not be long in coming.

Sure enough, a few minutes later, Archie turned to me.

"What happened in Muzillac, Horatio?

What indeed.  I hestiated before answering.  Indeed I hardly knew the answer myself.  The mission as we all knew from the start had been dammed.  However, that in itself was not enough to explain my actions.  How could I have treated Archie so badly.  I love Archie.  He is my soul mate, all I could ever want, ever need.  We have been lovers since El Ferrol.  Yet when he needed me I abandoned him.  Why did I do it?

Archie was feeling vulnerable being back on foreign soil.  I knew that and should have seen how difficult it was for him.  He tried to explain this to me on more than one occasion but I was not listening.  Instead, had mumbled some contrite nonsence about how the frogs could not hurt him and run off back to the village.  I was too wrapped up in the mission, myself and Marriette.

I can only explain it thus.  I lost myself.  On board the Indefatigable, there is order, duty, a sense of place, a sense of right and wrong.  The articles define our actions and above everything is the Captain.  I am familiar and comfortable with this.  I know what I must do, when it must be done and always near me is Archie.  As much a part of me and what I am as the uniform I wear.

In Muzillac was confusion.  The distinction between right and wrong disappeared.  There was no order, no command and I lost myself.  I forgot who I was, what I was.  The men, my duty, Archie, all became lost with it.

I met Mariette and for one brief moment dreamed of what it would be like to be normal.  Get married, have children.  We kissed.  It was a fantasy.  I felt nothing.  However, my foolish pride would not let me acknowledge that, to myself or her.  Instead, I persuaded her to come with me and killed her in the process.  

I believe that I shall carry the guilt with me for always.  For Mariette, for Archie, for my self indulgence.

Of course, Archie has never reproached me.  No, instead he ran across a bridge about to explode to save my life and has looked after me since our return.

He could not however, hide the hurt and the fear in his eyes as he turned to me and asked me the question.

I believed I knew what he feared, that I had turned to Mariette because I did not want him.  At least in this I was able to reassure him and tried to explain the rest as best I could.  When I had finished he said nothing.  Wanting to break the silence I bemoaned the fact that he had put his own life at risk to save mine and asked him to promise that he would never do so again.

He looked at me for a while, then slowly bent and kissed me gently on the lips before resting his head on my shoulder where he stayed before falling asleep.  No words were spoken, no promises made but I did not mind.  I knew that whatever wrongs I had done toward him, Archie had forgiven me and that was all that mattered.  I vowed there and then that never would my actions be the cause of any further hurt.

</lj-cut>

and here

Author: Grecian1
Title: Destiny
Pairing: H/A
Rating: Mild
Spoilers/Warnings: Don't worry.  No crumpets were killed or injured in the making of this fic.

Destiny

There is an old Arabic tale which goes something like this.  A servant was sent to the market by his master but returned shortly after in an extremely agitated state.  The master asked what was wrong.   The servant told him that he had seen Death in the market square and was convinced that the apparition had come for him.  He begged his master to let him leave, so was sent to a neighbouring town on an errand until the next day.

Later the same day, the master was at the market and he too saw the apparition of 'Death'  He asked him why he had scared his servant so much.  Death explained that he had not meant to alarm the servant but had been surprised to see him in the market square, as he had an appointment with him that evening in the neighbouring town.

Archie believes in destiny.  He would have it that destiny brought me to Justinian when I first joined the navy;  that is was destiny saw us both transferred to Indefatigable;  that is was destiny that took me to a small cell in El Ferrol and that it is destiny that sees us now both transferred together to Renown.  That most of all we were destined to be together in this life and I expect if you asked him, the next. 

I on the other hand, believe only in luck, good fortune and coincidence.  We have had many debates on the subject, usually after a jug or two of ale, in a drab room of some equally drab Inn, which usually go something like this.

'Horatio, out of all the ships in His Majesties Navy, how do you explain your posting to Justinian?  It was destiny Horatio, you were meant to be posted there in order to meet me!' 

This is usually followed by a self satisfied smile, the like of which Archie does so well and which always causes my heart to miss a beat. 

'Archie, I was posted to Justinian,  as you well know, because Captain Keene owed a debt to my father and wished to repay it in the best way he knew how.'

Feeling smug, I start to relax, assured that this is an argument I can win. 

'But, Horatio, that's the point.  There are hundreds of doctors in England and very few who have sons wanting to join the navy.  Is it not strange that your father should be the one to treat Captatin Keene when he needed it?'

At this stage of the proceedings, Archie, who can be devious when he needs to be, will begin his diversionary tactics.  They usually begin with a casual disrobing of his jacket followed by a very deliberate untying of his stock. 

'It was coincidence Archie, nothing more and nothing less.' 

I like to think I can be purposeful and once embarked on a course of action am not easily distracted.  I smile at Archie.  It will take more than a discarded jacket to alter my course. 

'Alright Horatio, but you cannot deny that it was more than coincidence that we ended up on Indefatigable together when two thirds of the crew went elsewhere'.

His queue is his next target.  Pulling the ribbon from his hair, and with a shake of the head, hair tumbles onto his shoulders.  God damn him!  He knows how much I love to see him with his hair undone.  However, this is still too easy and I know I am still in control.  I therefore allow my hand to rest on his shoulder, to feel his hair through my fingers. 

'Archie, we ended up on Indefatigable because Captain Keene had the good sense to send the only competent midshipmen he had to Captain Pellow.  That was simple common sense.' 

 Another look, this time the half glimpse with the subtle lick of the lips.  Oh no Archie, you will have to do better than that.

'Explain to me Mr Hornblower, if you will, how, out of all the prisons in Spain, you should end up at El Ferrol and in my cell'.

This always causes me to pause, for two reasons.  Firstly, I know how difficult it is for Archie to speak of this even now.  Secondly, because at times even I have problems in expaining this and hestitate to use the only reasonable explanation that I can come up with .  Meanwhile, Archie is now divesting himself of his shirt.  I am never failed to be moved (emotionally, and it has to be said physically) by the sight of Archie, shirtless, with his hair down and looking for all the world like the Belvedere Apollo. My hand inadvertantly drops down to trace through the smattering of hairs covering his chest.  However, I am determined for once to follow this argument through.

'It is quite simple Mr Kennedy.  The dons simply dropped us at the nearest prison to where we were captured.  It would then only be sensible to hold us in the same cell as you'.

By now,  I will often find myself up against the bedstead with a flushed and determined Archie Kennedy bearing down on me.  His eyes shine and hold mine.  He is beautiful and I almost fail to hear what he says next.  It is difficult to concentrate when you have someone astride your lap and fingers lightly caressing your face.

'What about the storm Horatio?  Was it not divine providence that the Indefatigable should find us after the rescue of the spanish sailors?'

'Horatio?'

Archie, who professes himself to be no tactician in battle can always take the appropriate action in our little skirmishes and will deal the final blow.  Hands reach to undo my breeches and all thought leaves.  I hear him say my name and gather my wits just enough to respond one last time.

'Archie, it was the Indefatigable which drove the ship onto the rocks in the first place.  Was it not inevitable then, that she would still be in the vicinity?'.

I can usually say no more and gladly concede the argument for the time being.  Archie, who by now is no more interested in talking than am I, will laugh softly to himself as he continues to assist me with my clothing.  However, I cannot help but smile ruefully to myself.  Maybe at times Archie has a point, for what happens next was certainly pre-ordained from the moment that the conversation began.  

Archie, still believes in destiny.  I still believe in luck and coincidence.  But at times like these it matters not what brought us together, only that something did.  I will allow myself to smile and look forward to debating the matter further on another occasion.

I have just created this journal, mainly because I enjoy reading everyone else's.  The only problem is I do not have any idea of what I am doing or how this works.  I guess I am going to have to learn as I go along (if I ever get further than this that is).

It cannot be too difficult can it?
